<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9702/51  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A thin cylindrical bar magnet of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\) is attached to a block. An identical magnet is attached to a trolley, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 824, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 260, 532, 279]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 769, 310]]<|/det|>
The trolley is held so that the separation of the N poles of the two magnets is \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 757, 341]]<|/det|>
Point P is a distance \(D\) from the N pole of the magnet on the stationary trolley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 890, 372]]<|/det|>
The trolley is released. The speed \(v\) of the trolley at point P is determined using one light gate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 562, 402]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to s by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 407, 586, 439]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{mv^2}{2D} = \frac{KA^2B^2L^2}{s^4} - Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 446, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
where \(B\) is the magnetic flux density at the N pole of one of the magnets, \(m\) is the mass of the trolley, and \(K\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 492, 690, 511]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 625, 542]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 553, 705, 572]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(K\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 384, 603]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 395, 634]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 645, 410, 663]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 348, 693]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 705, 351, 723]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 734, 447, 752]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates an electrical circuit. A power supply of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E_{\mathrm{s}}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected in series to three resistors, each of resistance Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
A cell, an ammeter and a resistor of resistance \(R\) are connected in parallel across one of these resistors, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 165, 700, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 670, 441]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) is measured by the ammeter for different values of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 571, 472]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(I\) and \(R\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 484, 588, 504]]<|/det|>
\[3E - E_{\mathrm{s}} = I(3R + 2Z)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 381, 533]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the e.m.f. of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 146, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 648, 567]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(R\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 611, 596]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 840, 917, 858]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 871, 917, 890]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 888, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 72, 490, 88]]<|/det|> Values of \(R\) and \(I\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 133, 789, 440]]<|/det|>
\(R/\mathrm {k}\Omega\)\(I/\upmu \mathrm {A}\)\(\frac {1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\)
1.50194±2
1.75180±2
1.92172±2
2.22160±2
2.48150±2
2.72144±2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 567, 472]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\frac {1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 475, 503]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\frac {1}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 918, 500]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 511, 144, 530]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 510, 176, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 508, 692, 536]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac {1}{I}/\mathrm {A}^{-1}\) against \(R/\mathrm {k}\Omega\). Include error bars for \(\frac {1}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 543, 178, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 542, 920, 577]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 588, 180, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 587, 920, 621]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 821, 920, 839]]<|/det|>
gradient = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 225, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 257, 180, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to **(a)**, **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)**, determine the values of \(E\) and \(Z\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 420, 322]]<|/det|>
Data: \(E_{\mathrm{s}} = (2.20 \pm 0.05)\mathrm{V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 440, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 472, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<form>Z = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 181, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 527, 539]]<|/det|>
Determine the absolute uncertainty in \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 675, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<form>absolute uncertainty in \(E =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 707, 146, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 890, 725]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the resistance \(R\) that gives a value of \(I\) of \(250 \mu \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 844, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 875, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 877, 920, 895]]<|/det|>
